choices.text: Immature Cataract

questions.text: Coloured halos are seen in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retinal Detachment

 

Option D: Coloured Halos are seen in Purulent Conjunctivitis, Cataract and Glaucoma.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Purulent Conjunctivitis–

 

Option B. Immature Cataract - As a cataract develops, changes in the lens can scatter light, leading to the perception of colored halos around lights.

 

Option C. Glaucoma - Acute angle-closure glaucoma can lead to the sudden onset of visual disturbances, including seeing colored halos around lights due to corneal edema caused by the elevated intraocular pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that colored halos are visual phenomena associated with corneal edema or lens changes, as seen in glaucoma and immature cataract, but not typically with retinal detachment.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 243

choices.text: Adjunctive Anti-Metabolites enhance the natural healing response at the site of filtration surgery.
Can be used intraoperatively.
Helps in bleb maintenance
Placed under the tenon’s capsule for 2 minutes.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding use of anti-metabolites in filtration surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adjunctive Anti-Metabolites enhance the natural healing response at the site of filtration surgery.

 

Option A:

 

  • Adjunctive antimetabolites INHIBIT the natural healing response at the site of filtration surgery that may preclude successful filtration surgery.
  • Helps in bleb formation.
  • E.g. 5-fluorouracil, Mitomycin C

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. This is true. Antimetabolites are often applied during filtration surgery. They can be applied to the surgical site for a brief period, usually a few minutes, to reduce postoperative scarring.

 

Option C. This is true. By inhibiting fibrosis and scarring, antimetabolites help in maintaining the function of the bleb, which is crucial for the success of filtration surgery in lowering intraocular pressure.

 

Option D. This is generally true. The application of antimetabolites like MMC is often performed by placing a sponge soaked with the drug under the Tenon’s capsule for a limited time, commonly around 2 to 5 minutes, depending on the concentration of the drug and the surgeon’s preference.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adjunctive anti metabolites are used in filtration surgery, such as trabeculectomy for inhibiting, not enhancing, the natural healing response at the surgical site. These agents are used intraoperatively to prevent postoperative scarring and fibrosis, thereby aiding in the maintenance of the bleb, essential for the surgery's success. Antimetabolites are typically applied under the Tenon’s capsule for a brief duration during the procedure.

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 339, 340

choices.text: Pan Retinal Photocoagulation

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyclo-Cryotherapy

 

Option B:

 

  • Cyclodestruction procedures aim to decrease intraocular pressure (IOP) by decreasing   production of aqueous humor by the ciliary body (specifically the ciliary processes).
  • Done for absolute glaucoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pan Retinal Photocoagulation is a laser treatment used primarily in the management of diabetic retinopathy and other retinal conditions. It involves applying laser burns to the retina, especially the peripheral areas, to reduce oxygen demand and prevent further retinal damage. It does not involve the ciliary body or the use of a cryoprobe.

 

Option C. Peripheral Iridectomy is surgical procedure that involves the removal of a small portion of the peripheral iris. It's commonly used in the treatment of angle-closure glaucoma to create an alternative pathway for aqueous humor to flow from the posterior to the anterior chamber, thus relieving pupillary block.

 

Option D. Goniotomy is a surgical procedure used primarily in the treatment of congenital glaucoma. It involves making an incision in the trabecular meshwork, the eye's drainage system, to improve the outflow of aqueous humor and lower intraocular pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclo-cryotherapy is the ophthalmic procedure where a cryoprobe is applied to the ciliary body. It is typically used in the management of advanced or refractory glaucoma cases to decrease aqueous humor production.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 219

questions.text: A patient with a failed trabeculectomy was taken up for re-surgery. Which of the following adjuvants is preferred to reduce recurrence?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mitomycin C

 

Option B:

 

  • Antimetabolites are agents used in various ocular surgeries to prevent fibroblastic response.
  • The agents commonly used include:
    • 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU)
    • Mitomycin C(MMC)
  • 5-FU - 50 mg/ml it can be placed under the conjunctiva intraoperatively or administered as subconjunctival injections of 5 mg/ml daily or on alternate days, up to a total dose of 50 mg.
  • Topical drops of 0.2–0.4 mg/ml of MMC have been used daily after pterygium surgery to reduce scarring and recurrences.
  • A sponge soaked in 0.2–0.4 mg/ml of MMC is placed subconjunctivally or between the two scleral layers during surgery for a duration of 1–3 minutes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cyclosporin: Immunosuppressant. Calcineurin inhibitor; binds cyclophilin.

 

Option C. Tacrolimus: Immunosuppressant. Calcineurin inhibitor; binds FK506 binding protein.

 

Option D. Riboflavin: Vitamin B2. Deficiency causes corneal revascularization, cheilosis, magenta tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antimetabolites used for as adjuvants in trabeculectomy are 5-Fluorouracil and Mitomycin-C.

 

Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22nd Edition Page:160

questions.text: Which of the following carbonic anhydrase inhibitors is used topically in glaucoma treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brinzolamide

 

Option A: Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors block the action of Carbonic Anhydrase and reduce the production of Aqueous in the eye.

 

Topical Preparations:

 

  • 2% Dorzolamide
  • 1% Brinzolamide

 

Explanation:

 

Oral Preparations of Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors are:

 

Option B: Acetazolamide

 

Option C: Dichlorphenamide

 

Option D: Methazolamide

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brinzolamide and Dorzolamide the topical preparations of Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors used to reduce intraocular pressure in Glaucoma.

 

Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22nd Edition Page: 157

questions.text: A surgeon noticed an increase in Intraocular pressure after inducing Anesthesia. What could be the possible drug used?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketamine

 

Option A: Ketamine, a dissociative anesthetic, is known to increase intraocular pressure. It stimulates the central nervous system and can cause an increase in sympathetic tone, leading to elevated IOP. This makes it less desirable for use in patients with glaucoma or other conditions where increased IOP is a concern.

 

Anesthetic Drugs affecting intra-ocular pressure

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Opioids like morphine typically do not significantly affect intraocular pressure. In fact, some opioids can decrease IOP, although this is not a primary effect and may not be clinically significant.

 

Option C. Diazepam, a benzodiazepine, generally does not significantly increase intraocular pressure. It is often used in anesthesia for its sedative and anxiolytic effects.

 

Option D. Fentanyl, another opioid, is similar to morphine in that it does not typically increase intraocular pressure. In fact, it may slightly decrease IOP, but like morphine, this effect is not usually significant in the clinical setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the given options, ketamine is known to increase intraocular pressure, making it a less preferable choice in patients where elevated IOP is a concern, such as those with glaucoma.

 

Ref: Pg 94/Anatomy and Physiology of Eye/AK KHURANA/3rd Edition

choices.text: Aqueous Humour
Blood Plasma
Vitreous Humour

questions.text: Mannitol is a Hyperosmotic Agent used to Lower Intraocular Pressure. Where does it draw water from?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitreous Humour

 

Option C:

 

  • Hyperosmotic agents like mannitol penetrate the eye poorly because of the blood ocular barrier.
  • Mannitol ‘draws-out’ water from vitreous into the blood by creating an osmotic gradient and causes a reduction in intraocular pressure.
  • It is to be avoided in patients with cardiac and renal disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aqueous Humour: While mannitol does affect the aqueous humour, its primary action isn't directly drawing water from the aqueous humour. The reduction in intraocular pressure following mannitol administration is more a result of the overall decrease in vascular volume within the eye.

 

Option B. Blood plasma: Mannitol works by creating an osmotic gradient between the blood plasma and ocular tissues. It is administered intravenously and increases the osmolality of the blood plasma. However, mannitol does not draw water from the blood plasma; rather, it draws water into the blood plasma from surrounding tissues.

 

Option D. Cornea: While the cornea does contain water, mannitol's primary action in reducing intraocular pressure is not focused on drawing water directly from the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mannitol, a hyperosmotic agent, reduces intraocular pressure by drawing water from the vitreous humour into the blood plasma, thereby decreasing the volume of ocular fluids and the intraocular pressure.

 

Ref: pg 79/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA; Pg 407/ Ch. 11 Glaucoma/ 9th Edition/ Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypermetropic patient with a shallow anterior chamber came for an ophthalmic consultation. Post administration of a drug in the right eye, the patient developed pain and redness in the right eye associated with headache. The drug inducing this would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tropicamide

 

Option B: In a hypermetropic patient with shallow anterior chamber, use of cycloplegics result in mydriasis resulting in crowding of the angle – this results in acute angle closure attack.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rimexolone is a corticosteroid used in ophthalmology primarily for its anti-inflammatory effects. Steroids like rimexolone can increase intraocular pressure, particularly in individuals predisposed to open-angle glaucoma, but they are not typically associated with causing angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine is a miotic agent that constricts the pupil. Pilocarpine is actually used in the treatment of angle-closure glaucoma because it pulls the iris away from the trabecular meshwork, opening the anterior chamber angle and facilitating aqueous humor outflow.

 

Option D. Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue used to lower intraocular pressure in open-angle glaucoma and ocular hypertension. It is not known to cause angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tropicamide, a mydriatic agent that dilates the pupil, can precipitate angle-closure glaucoma in susceptible individuals.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 155

questions.text: Which drug is responsible for the presentation given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

 

Option C:

 

  • The picture shows hyperpigmentation of iris and periocular skin.
  • Irreversible iris hyperpigmentation is noted in patient with topical use of prostaglandin analogues.
  • It is caused by an increase in the number of pigmented granules within the superficial stroma rather than an increase in the number of melanocytes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Olopatadine is an antihistamine used primarily for the treatment of allergic conjunctivitis. Olopatadine is not commonly associated with iris hyperpigmentation.

 

Option B. Epinephrine (adrenaline) is not typically associated with causing iris hyperpigmentation. Its primary ocular effects are related to its sympathomimetic activity.

 

Option D. Apraclonidine is an alpha agonist used to reduce intraocular pressure in glaucoma. Apraclonidine is not known to cause iris hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue used in the treatment of glaucoma and ocular hypertension, is associated with causing iris hyperpigmentation by increasing melanin production in the stromal melanocytes of the iris.

 

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 404

choices.text: Degraded by Corneal Protease
NO – Donating PG Analogue
Increases Uveoscleral Outflow
Increases Trabecular Outflow

questions.text: All the following statements are true about latanoprostenebunod except which one?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Degraded by Corneal Protease.

 

Option A: Upon topical administration, LBN is hydrolysed by endogenous corneal esterases into latanoprost acid and butanediol mononitrate, which is further metabolized to NO and the inactive 1, 4-butanediol.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. NO – donating PG analogue: Latanoprostenebunod is a Nitric Oxide (NO)-donating prostaglandin F2α analogue. Its unique feature is that it releases nitric oxide upon hydrolysis, which contributes to its intraocular pressure-lowering effects.

 

Option C. Increases uveoscleral outflow: The primary mechanism of action of prostaglandin analogues, like latanoprostenebunod, is to increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option D. Increases Trabecular Outflow: The NO-donating aspect of this drug mediates increase in Trabecular Outflow.

 

Ref: AAO SECTION: 2 – 2020 EDITION PAGE 395; Hoy SM. LatanoprosteneBunod Ophthalmic Solution 0.024%: A Review in Open-Angle Glaucoma and Ocular Hypertension. Drugs. 2018 May; 78(7):773-780. doi: 10.1007/s40265-018-0914-6. Erratum in: Drugs. 2018 Jun; 78(8):857. PMID: 29761382; PMCID: PMC5976683

choices.text: Increases Trabecular Outflow
Decreases Episcleral Venous Pressure
Decreases Aqueous Production
Increases Uveoscleral Outflow

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism through which Netarsudil acts?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increases Uveoscleral Outflow

 

Option D. Netarsudil does not significantly increase uveoscleral outflow. Prostaglandin analogues act by reducing uveoscleral outflow.

 

  • Netarsudil is an inhibitor of both ROCK and the norepinephrine transporter.
  • It is thought to work via 3 mechanisms:
    • Increase of trabecular outflow
    • Reduction of episcleral venous pressure by ROCK inhibition
    • Reduction of aqueous production by norepinephrine transporter inhibition

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increasing trabecular outflow facilitates the outflow of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork pathway, thereby lowering intraocular pressure.

 

Option B. By inhibiting Rho kinase, Netarsudil can also lead to a decrease in episcleral venous pressure, contributing to its pressure-lowering effect.

 

Option C. Decreasing aqueous production: Although not its primary mechanism, Netarsudil may slightly reduce the production of aqueous humor, further aiding in the reduction of intraocular pressure.

 

Educational objective:

 

Netarsudil lowers intraocular pressure primarily by increasing trabecular outflow and decreasing episcleral venous pressure, but it does not significantly increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

Ref: AAO Section: 2 – 2020 Edition Page 396; Kaufman AR, Elhusseiny AM, Edward DP, Vajaranant TS, Aref AA, Abbasian J. Topical Netarsudil for treatment of Glaucoma with Elevated Episcleral Venous Pressure: A Pilot investigation in Sturge-Weber Syndrome. Eur J Ophthalmol. 2023 Sep; 33(5):1969-1976. doi: 10.1177/11206721231159694. Epub 2023 Feb 27. PMID: 36850063.
